Title: Linking forum posts -smac-001-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: How does Barbier recover a/b in 2/pi a/b
Input.posts:
At 16:30, by pure thinking we see that Barbier recovered $$ \langle N_{\mathrm{hits}}\rangle= \dfrac{a}{b} \dfrac2\pi $$ So far as I can tell the lecture only covered the case where $$a=b$$, and each circle had exactly two hits. Does the factor $$a/b$$ come from noticing that when $$b>a$$ the circle is uniformly distributed and hence chance of getting 2 hits is $$a/b$$? (the chance of getting 1 hit is still zero)
Upvotes:
0
Maybe there is a little inconsistency in the lecture. At around 14:20, straight needles of length $$a=\pi b$$ are thrown. Later on, I believe round needles of length $$a=\pi b$$ should also be thrown (but the lecture says they are of length $$\pi$$). For such round needles, Barbier found that $$=2$$ always. Since $$=\Upsilon a$$, for round needles with $$a=\pi b$$, it implies $$\Upsilon = \frac{2}{\pi b}$$. Apparently, somewhere in the lecture, $$b$$ is taken to be 1.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Dear Tsu-Liang and Tony, dear all, Thanks for the remarks... You 'hit' a point that would have deserved more discussion (but I was already at 32 minutes): The number of hits must be a dimension-less number. a has dimensions of 'centimeter' or 'inch', and a * 2 / pi has also the dimension of centimeter. So it is necessarily a/b times something, and you can get the result by taking b=1. This procedure is standard for physicists. I see that you still got the picture. Another point that I did not dwell on in detail is the passage from the initial computation, where the 'acos x' appeared, and that was only valid for a < b, to the gadget No1, which is clearly valid for arbitrary a. This is a key scene in the whole plot that I hope nobody missed. Best, Werner

Input.posts:
I completely lost it at the point where x goes to $$\pm\infty$$. I thought x was a random number sampled between 0 and 1 or maybe it's now the observable $$x^\gamma$$, or perhaps it's the variable in the Levy distribution. Anyway I don't get how as $$x\to\infty$$ we have $$1.25 / x^{2.25}$$ and for $$x\to-\infty$$ we have 0. Please can someone shed any light on this?
Upvotes:

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Hi Tony, thanks for the question.. Remember Vivien, in tutorial 4, explaining that a random number random.uniform(0.0, 1.0) taken to some power alpha was not distributed as x^\alpha. Rather, Vivien found was to have a distribution x^alpha (for 1 < x < infty) you needed to take random.uniform ^(1/ alpha + 1). In other words alpha = 1/gamma - 1... Since gamma was - 4/5 you find alpha = -2.25. To understand what is happening, simply do the histogram of random.uniform^(-0.8)... You will find out that this quantity (that we call Sigma/N for N=1) is distributed as 1.25 / (Sigma/N)^2.25 for x > 1, and 0 for x < 1. See Tutorial 4. In particular, you find that the asymptotic behavior of this function is 1.25 / (Sigma/N)^2.25 in the limit + infty and 0 in the limit -infty. I hope that helps, Werner PS: In this last part, we are in deep waters. First try to run the programs...

This is about B2: Can 5 blue spheres really touched each other in an 'all pair' manner while sticking to the surface of the red sphere? Or this is touching in the sense of a 'spanning tree', ie. some spheres in this set of 5 don't directly touch each other, but they indirectly do by intermediate spheres. A 5-connected disk is simply one that touches 5 other other disks. In some configurations all such disks touch every other such disk (you can probably guess how many there are then), but in others they do not. 'Touch' has to be interpreted approximately. If you're reading the output files to do this, like I did, you don't know the radius of the disks and need to infer it from the given configuration. If you assume at least one pair of disks touch, that will give you the value of 2*radius against which you can compare all other separations. Other 'touching' disks won't have that exact same separation but it will be very close (relative difference of 10^-4 or so).

What follows is the result of my investigations (and of not knowing Topology) so, please correct me when it's wrong: A 1-connected manifold just means, a simply connected manifold, that is, a manifold without singularities. In this context, it would be a disk that (usually, or with high probability) does not touch any other disk. Like the 'rattler' term in B3 is suggesting. By the way, the fact that it does touch the central sphere is not relevant, because we're analyzing the connectedness of the spheres on the surface of the central sphere among themselves, and without considering the central sphere. By following the same logic, a 5-connected manifold would be a manifold with 4 singularities. That is, in this context, a disk that is 'connected', or touches, four neighbouring disks. Now, in the 15-sphere optimal packing there can be more than one of these 5-connected manifolds. Now, in one configuration containing a number of these 5-connected manifolds, all these 5-connected manifolds 'touch each other'. That is, simply, that they form a bigger, all-connected cluster. Now, it seems that the only way that can happen, if it can happen at all, in the context of the 15-sphere optimal packing, is related to rotational symmetry. Now, the question is, am I even remotely correct? Update: Of course, I'm not. :-) See below, and Neil Carlson's posts above.

Input.inst_post:

Dear Boris, thanks for the question. The problem is the following: In markov_ising.py: you choose spin k with proba 1/N and then you attempt a flip with p_k ... this moves you ahead by one timestep In dynamic_ising.py, you sample the time for the next event by tower-sampling in lambda. Then (knowing that at this time, an event is happening) you decide which spin to flip , and you have to sample this from pi_0, pi_1,...., pi_{N-1} I am very happy to see that there is a discussion started on this point. It is really essential. It is not a trivial point. Best, Werner

Input.threadtitle: What about Fermions?
Input.posts:
I realise that this is beyond our scope, but what modifications should we make to our algorithm for the case of indistinguishable particles which obey Fermi statistics?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Dear Torcuato... Thanks for the question... Fermions (...many years of my life....) can be treated through determinantal Monte Carlo, a beautiful algorithm that would be week 10 and 11 of our course, if it lasted 12 weeks. In a nutshell, it consists in reducing the very complicated fermion interaction to a special case of classical Ising model. The problem with fermions is that it leads to so much more suffering, pain, sweat, deceptions because of the socalled Fermion sign problem. Although we are quite experts in Fermion Monte Carlo, we decided at some point in the design process to leave it out: Just no way to fire up a short Fermion program that can (almost) be compared to experiment, as is easy for Bosons... Thanks for asking, Best greeting fom Paris, Werner

I realise that this is beyond our scope, but what modifications should we make to our algorithm for the case of indistinguishable particles which obey Fermi statistics?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Dear Torcuato... Thanks for the question... Fermions (...many years of my life....) can be treated through determinantal Monte Carlo, a beautiful algorithm that would be week 10 and 11 of our course, if it lasted 12 weeks. In a nutshell, it consists in reducing the very complicated fermion interaction to a special case of classical Ising model. The problem with fermions is that it leads to so much more suffering, pain, sweat, deceptions because of the socalled Fermion sign problem. Although we are quite experts in Fermion Monte Carlo, we decided at some point in the design process to leave it out: Just no way to fire up a short Fermion program that can (almost) be compared to experiment, as is easy for Bosons... Thanks for asking, Best greeting fom Paris, Werner
